subtopics.subtopic_title: Definition and classification of overnutrition
subtopics.concept: Overnutrition, encompassing overweight and obesity, is classified based on anthropometric indices that measure excessive weight relative to height or age. For children under five years, overnutrition is defined as a weight-for-length or weight-for-height above +2 standard deviations (SD) on WHO growth charts. In children aged 5–18 years, body mass index (BMI)-for-age is the standard metric, with the Indian Academy of Pediatrics (IAP) 2015 growth charts providing BMI percentiles aligned to adult-equivalent cut-offs. A BMI corresponding to an adult-equivalent of 23 kg/m² marks overweight, while 27 kg/m² indicates obesity, which roughly aligns with the 85th and 95th percentiles on IAP BMI curves for age and sex. Obesity is further stratified into severity classes: Class 1 obesity refers to a BMI just above the 27-equivalent cut-off; Class 2 obesity is defined as a BMI ≥120% of the 27-equivalent cut-off (approximately BMI ≥35 kg/m² in older adolescents); and Class 3 obesity, or extreme obesity, is defined as a BMI ≥140% of the 27-equivalent cut-off or about ≥40 kg/m², whichever is lower for the child’s age. Central adiposity, an additional marker of overnutrition, is assessed using waist circumference, with values above the 90th percentile for age and gender indicating abdominal obesity and heightened cardiometabolic risk. For Asian Indian children, who often exhibit a “thin-fat” phenotype with higher body fat and metabolic risk at lower BMIs, a waist circumference threshold of ≥70th percentile has been suggested for screening. Adolescents are further categorized into early (10–13 years), middle (14–16 years), and late (17–19 years) phases to account for variations in growth and nutritional needs during puberty. By systematically applying growth charts, BMI percentiles, and waist circumference measures, clinicians can identify overweight and obesity, assess severity, and tailor interventions to mitigate associated health risks.

subtopics.subtopic_title: Epidemiology of childhood obesity in India
subtopics.concept:
Childhood obesity has emerged as a significant public health challenge globally and in India, with a steady rise in prevalence over recent decades. Worldwide, approximately 18% of school-aged children, or an estimated 200 million youth, are overweight or obese, with low- and middle-income countries experiencing rapid increases due to nutrition transitions. India faces a dual burden of malnutrition, where overnutrition coexists with persistent undernutrition. By 2017, India had an estimated 14.4 million obese children, ranking second globally after China. Data from the Comprehensive National Nutrition Survey (2016–18) revealed that 4% of Indian children aged 5–9 years and 5% of adolescents aged 10–19 years are overweight, while 1% in each group meet criteria for obesity. However, these national averages obscure significant regional and urban-rural disparities. Urban centers, particularly affluent populations, report higher prevalence rates, with city-based studies indicating combined overweight/obesity rates ranging from approximately 5% to as high as 30%. A meta-analysis of 52 Indian studies demonstrated an increase in combined overweight/obesity prevalence from 16.3% in the early 2000s to 19.3% after 2010, underscoring a consistent upward trend. Alarmingly, the severity of obesity is also escalating, with more children presenting with class 2 or class 3 obesity. The COVID-19 pandemic further exacerbated this issue, as lockdowns and reduced physical activity contributed to weight gain in many children. 

Childhood obesity in India is influenced by various risk factors, including urbanization, dietary transitions toward energy-dense foods, sedentary lifestyles, and socioeconomic status. Urban areas, particularly among affluent families, exhibit higher rates of childhood obesity due to greater access to calorie-rich foods and reduced physical activity opportunities. Caregivers play a crucial role in prevention by fostering healthy dietary habits, encouraging regular physical activity, and limiting screen time. Public health efforts must also address broader systemic issues, such as improving access to nutritious foods and creating environments conducive to active lifestyles, to mitigate the growing epidemic of childhood obesity in India.

subtopics.subtopic_title: Genetic and epigenetic factors in childhood overnutrition
subtopics.concept: Childhood overnutrition results from a multifaceted interplay of genetic, environmental, and behavioral factors, fundamentally driven by a sustained energy imbalance where caloric intake exceeds expenditure. Genetic and familial influences are significant, with children of overweight parents having a 40% risk of obesity if one parent is obese and up to an 80% risk if both parents are obese. This heightened risk arises from both genetic predispositions and shared family environments. Polygenic factors may enhance fat storage efficiency or appetite, while rare monogenic disorders, such as leptin or MC4R mutations, and genetic syndromes like Prader-Willi and Bardet-Biedl, contribute to severe early-onset obesity in less than 5-10% of cases. Prenatal and early life factors also play a critical role. Maternal overnutrition, pre-pregnancy BMI ≥30, excessive gestational weight gain, or gestational diabetes mellitus increase the likelihood of childhood obesity. Paradoxically, intrauterine growth restriction and low birth weight, often linked to maternal undernutrition, can elevate obesity risk if followed by rapid catch-up growth in infancy. Feeding practices in infancy are pivotal; short exclusive breastfeeding durations (<6 months) are associated with higher obesity odds, while longer breastfeeding is protective. Early introduction of sugar-sweetened beverages or fruit juices in infancy raises obesity risk 4-5-fold. Dietary habits further exacerbate the issue, with energy-dense, nutrient-poor diets—rich in processed foods, sugary beverages, and oversized portions—promoting weight gain. Parental feeding behaviors, such as overfeeding or using food as a reward, can disrupt children’s natural hunger cues, while hidden sugars and high salt content in processed foods encourage overconsumption. Physical inactivity and sedentary behaviors, including reduced outdoor play, less walking or cycling, and increased screen time, are strongly associated with obesity. Screen exposure not only reduces energy expenditure but also encourages snacking and food advertising exposure. Poor sleep habits, such as short or irregular sleep, further disrupt appetite-regulating hormones, compounding weight gain. Together, these genetic, epigenetic, and lifestyle factors underscore the complexity of childhood overnutrition and highlight modifiable risk factors essential for targeted interventions.

subtopics.subtopic_title: Cultural and socioeconomic factors influencing dietary habits
subtopics.concept: Cultural and socioeconomic factors significantly influence dietary habits in India, shaping distinct nutritional patterns among children. Undernutrition remains prevalent in rural and impoverished areas, where children often exhibit low weight for age, stunting by age two, and visible micronutrient deficiencies such as sparse, discolored hair or skin depigmentation in severe protein-energy malnutrition. Vitamin A deficiency, marked by Bitot’s spots, is also common. A unique Indian variant is the coexistence of micronutrient malnutrition even in children who are not severely underweight, largely due to diets dominated by polished rice and wheat, which lack dietary diversity. Over 50% of Indian children older than one year suffer from iron deficiency anemia, with zinc and B-vitamin deficiencies also widespread. Cultural practices further contribute to undernutrition; prolonged breastfeeding with delayed complementary feeding is common in some communities, while vegetarian diets often exclude animal foods, leading to vitamin B<sub>12</sub> and iron deficiencies. Gender bias exacerbates the issue in certain regions, with girl children more likely to be undernourished or brought late for treatment. Conversely, urban middle-class children increasingly face overnutrition, presenting with rapid weight gain, early-onset obesity (BMI above the 95th percentile), and pediatric insulin resistance. This often coexists with micronutrient deficits, termed “hidden hunger,” where overweight children consuming energy-rich but nutrient-poor processed foods exhibit deficiencies in vitamin D or iron. The “thin-fat” Indian child phenomenon is another notable variant, where children may not appear obese by BMI criteria but have excess body fat and central adiposity, increasing metabolic risks such as acanthosis and dyslipidemia. Indian children often require lower BMI cut-offs for overweight classification, and waist circumference and metabolic parameters should be assessed even in mildly overweight cases. Additionally, the gut microbiome of Indian children, shaped by high environmental microbial exposure, differs from Western counterparts, potentially influencing responses to probiotics or synbiotics. Addressing India’s double burden of persistent undernutrition and rising pediatric obesity requires nutrition programs tailored to local diets, such as incorporating indigenous foods like millets to improve dietary quality.

subtopics.subtopic_title: Sedentary lifestyle and metabolic risk
subtopics.concept: In the Indian context, pediatric overnutrition presents unique patterns that highlight the interplay between genetic, cultural, dietary, and lifestyle factors, contributing to a sedentary lifestyle and metabolic risk. A notable phenomenon is the “thin-fat” Indian child, where children may not appear obese by BMI criteria but carry excess body fat and central adiposity, predisposing them to metabolic risks such as insulin resistance and dyslipidemia. Indian and other South Asian children typically exhibit higher body fat percentages and central fat deposition at a given BMI compared to Caucasian peers. Consequently, even a child with a BMI in the high-normal range or at the 80th percentile may demonstrate obesity-related complications, such as acanthosis nigricans, fatty liver, or a large waist circumference (>90th percentile). This has led to the adoption of lower BMI cut-offs for overweight (adult BMI 23) in Asian populations and underscores the importance of assessing waist circumference and metabolic parameters in mildly overweight Indian children. Cultural perceptions further influence the recognition of obesity. In traditional Indian households, particularly in rural or semi-urban areas, chubby children are often viewed as healthy, delaying acknowledgment of obesity as a health issue. Conversely, urban parents, with greater health awareness, may seek early intervention even for children who are only moderately overweight. Dietary habits also play a critical role; high consumption of carbohydrate-rich staples like rice and wheat, often paired with ghee and sugar, increases caloric intake. Affluent families may combine traditional high-calorie foods with Western fast foods, compounding the risk. Vegetarian diets, common in India, can be imbalanced, with excessive refined carbohydrates and inadequate protein, promoting fat gain. Urban children face additional risks from “academic pressure obesity,” where long hours of study and tuition, limited outdoor play (due to safety concerns), and frequent snacking lead to sedentary lifestyles and increased screen exposure. Pediatricians must remain vigilant for secondary causes of obesity, such as genetic syndromes (e.g., Prader-Willi, Bardet-Biedl) or endocrine disorders like hypothyroidism, particularly in regions with a history of iodine deficiency. Regional differences in obesity prevalence, such as higher rates in North India, may reflect dietary patterns like higher fat intake. Recognizing these multifactorial contributors is essential for tailoring effective interventions.

subtopics.subtopic_title: Impact of screen time on physical and metabolic health
subtopics.concept: The impact of screen time on physical and metabolic health in children is a growing concern, as excessive screen use is closely linked to overnutrition and obesity, which can manifest through various clinical features. Obesity in children is often identified either incidentally during routine health visits or school health checks, where weight or BMI is noted to exceed recommended percentiles, or through symptom-driven presentations. Parents may report rapid increases in clothing sizes, or that their child is taller and heavier than peers, often accompanied by a history of high appetite and preferences for sedentary activities like screen time. Early obesity is frequently asymptomatic apart from visible weight gain, but it may also present with complications such as excessive daytime fatigue, breathlessness, or joint pains during physical activity. Psychosocial concerns, including low self-esteem, social withdrawal, and depression, are common, with obese children being at a 32% higher risk of depression compared to their non-obese peers. Adolescents may exhibit cosmetic concerns like stretch marks or gynecomastia, or puberty-related issues such as menstrual irregularities and hirsutism in girls, suggestive of polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), or delayed puberty in boys due to the hormonal effects of excess adipose tissue. Clinicians should carefully assess growth charts for upward crossing of weight percentiles relative to height, as well as physical signs of adiposity, particularly central fat accumulation and features like acanthosis nigricans, which indicates hyperinsulinemia. Early obesity may also spur a growth spurt, making affected children taller than their peers. Mild hypertension may be detected if blood pressure is measured carefully. Persistent or worsening obesity can lead to more pronounced central fat distribution, poor exercise tolerance, obstructive sleep apnea, and orthopedic issues such as flat feet, genu valgum, or slipped capital femoral epiphysis. Adolescents may present with oligomenorrhea, androgen excess, or delayed pubertal progression. Recognizing these signs early and addressing screen time as a modifiable risk factor is crucial in mitigating the physical and metabolic sequelae of obesity in children.

subtopics.subtopic_title: Comorbidities of childhood obesity (e.g., Type 2 diabetes, hypertension)
subtopics.concept: Childhood obesity is a multifactorial condition resulting from a chronic imbalance between calorie intake and energy expenditure, influenced by dietary habits, lifestyle factors, and genetic predisposition. Excess fat accumulation in children involves both hypertrophy (enlargement of fat cells) and hyperplasia (increase in fat cell number), particularly during critical developmental windows such as the adiposity rebound, which typically occurs around 5–6 years of age. An early adiposity rebound, defined as a rise in BMI before 5 years, strongly predicts obesity in adolescence and adulthood, suggesting a potential upward shift in the body’s adiposity “set-point.” Insulin resistance (IR) is central to the metabolic complications of obesity, driven by the release of free fatty acids and pro-inflammatory cytokines from visceral fat. This leads to compensatory hyperinsulinemia, which can manifest clinically as acanthosis nigricans, a velvety hyperpigmentation of the skin in body folds. Persistent IR can progress to impaired glucose tolerance and type 2 diabetes if unaddressed. Obesity also disrupts endocrine and inflammatory pathways, with excess adipose tissue acting as an endocrine organ that secretes hormones like leptin and inflammatory mediators such as TNF-α and IL-6. Leptin resistance, common in obesity, contributes to overeating, while low-grade systemic inflammation promotes endothelial dysfunction and early atherosclerosis. Many obese children exhibit components of metabolic syndrome, including IR, dyslipidemia (high triglycerides, low HDL), hypertension, and central obesity. In Indian children aged 10–18 years with obesity, nearly 46% have metabolic syndrome. Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD), now termed metabolic dysfunction-associated steatotic liver disease (MASLD), is another common comorbidity, affecting approximately one-third of obese children. Risk factors for MASLD include age >10 years, male sex, Asian ethnicity, severe obesity, and a family history of type 2 diabetes or metabolic syndrome. MASLD often progresses silently, with elevated alanine aminotransferase (ALT) levels serving as a key diagnostic marker. In children, ALT upper limits are lower than in adults, approximately <22 U/L for girls and <26 U/L for boys, with levels exceeding 2× these thresholds suggesting significant liver involvement. Early identification and management of these comorbidities are critical to mitigating long-term health risks.

subtopics.subtopic_title: Psychosocial factors contributing to overnutrition
subtopics.concept: Psychosocial factors play a significant role in the development and perpetuation of overnutrition in children, influencing both its onset and clinical presentation. Children with overnutrition often come to clinical attention either through routine screening or due to symptom-driven concerns. A common scenario involves parents bringing a school-age child or adolescent to the clinic because they perceive the child as “too heavy” or failing to outgrow baby fat. Such children may otherwise feel well, as early obesity is often asymptomatic apart from visible weight gain. However, psychosocial concerns frequently emerge, particularly in older children and adolescents. For instance, an adolescent girl may express distress over weight gain and stretch marks, while a boy may report being teased at school. These experiences can lead to low self-esteem, social withdrawal, and symptoms of depression, with obese children having a 32% higher risk of depression compared to their non-obese peers. In clinical practice, it is essential to recognize the psychosocial dimensions of overnutrition, as they can significantly impact a child’s well-being and treatment adherence. Parents may report that their child prefers sedentary activities, such as screen time, and has a strong appetite for calorie-dense snacks, which can perpetuate weight gain. Social stigma, bullying, and body image concerns are common, particularly among adolescents, and may manifest as avoidance of social interactions or reluctance to participate in physical activities. Additionally, adolescents with obesity may present with puberty-related concerns, such as menstrual irregularities or hirsutism in girls, suggestive of polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), or delayed pubertal progression in boys, potentially exacerbating their psychosocial distress. Addressing these psychosocial factors requires a sensitive and nonjudgmental approach. Clinicians should inquire about the child’s emotional well-being, peer relationships, and school experiences while fostering a supportive environment for both the child and their family. Early identification and intervention targeting these psychosocial contributors, alongside medical management, are critical for improving outcomes in children with overnutrition.

subtopics.subtopic_title: Role of physical activity and structured exercise programs
subtopics.concept: The role of physical activity and structured exercise programs is pivotal in managing pediatric overnutrition, particularly in mitigating its clinical features and associated complications. Physical activity serves as a cornerstone for improving energy balance, enhancing cardiorespiratory fitness, and addressing the early and late manifestations of obesity. Children with overnutrition often present with signs such as excessive weight gain relative to height, upward crossing of weight percentiles on growth charts, and central adiposity, which can be observed as a prominent abdominal girth or accumulation of subcutaneous fat around the triceps or waist. Early physical symptoms, such as fatigue, breathlessness during play, or difficulty keeping up with peers, highlight the importance of incorporating exercise to improve endurance and overall physical function. Structured exercise programs can also target obesity-related orthopedic issues, such as knee pain, flat feet, or genu valgum, by strengthening musculoskeletal support and reducing joint stress. In adolescents, physical activity is particularly beneficial for addressing puberty-related concerns, such as oligomenorrhea or androgen excess in girls with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) and delayed puberty or gynecomastia in boys. Regular exercise can help regulate hormonal imbalances by reducing adiposity and improving insulin sensitivity, as evidenced by the association of obesity with hyperinsulinemia and acanthosis nigricans. Furthermore, structured activity can alleviate psychosocial concerns, such as low self-esteem, social withdrawal, and depression, which are more prevalent in obese children, who face a 32% higher risk of depression compared to their non-obese peers. For bedside decision-making, it is essential to tailor physical activity recommendations to the child’s age, developmental stage, and baseline fitness level. Programs should emphasize enjoyable, age-appropriate activities that encourage sustained participation, such as team sports, swimming, or cycling. Gradual progression in intensity and duration is key to avoiding injury, particularly in children with orthopedic complications. Additionally, addressing barriers like fatigue or low motivation through family involvement and behavioral strategies can enhance adherence. Ultimately, integrating physical activity into a comprehensive management plan can significantly improve both the physical and psychosocial outcomes of pediatric overnutrition.

subtopics.subtopic_title: Nutritional counseling and dietary interventions for obese children
subtopics.concept: In the Indian context, pediatric obesity presents unique variant patterns influenced by genetic, cultural, dietary, and socioeconomic factors. One notable phenomenon is the “thin-fat” Indian child, characterized by higher body fat percentage and central adiposity at a given BMI compared to Caucasian peers. Indian children may exhibit obesity-related complications, such as acanthosis or dyslipidemia, even with BMI values in the high-normal range. This has led to lower BMI cut-offs for Asian populations, with adult BMI ≥23 considered overweight, emphasizing the importance of measuring waist circumference and metabolic parameters. For instance, a child with a BMI at the 80th percentile (not meeting Western obesity criteria) but a waist circumference >90th percentile may already show signs of fatty liver, a pattern common in Indian children due to central fat deposition and insulin resistance at lower BMI thresholds. Socio-cultural factors further influence obesity recognition; in traditional Indian households, especially rural or semi-urban areas, chubby children are often perceived as healthy, delaying intervention. Pediatricians may need to counsel families to reframe this perception. Conversely, urban families with greater health awareness may seek advice even for children with moderate weight gain, reflecting varied perceptions across regions. Dietary habits also play a significant role. High consumption of carbohydrate-rich staples like rice and wheat, often combined with ghee and sugar, increases calorie intake even in vegetarian diets. Affluent families may compound this risk with access to both traditional high-calorie foods (e.g., sweets, fried snacks) and Western fast foods. Vegetarian diets, common in India, may be imbalanced, with excessive refined carbohydrates and inadequate protein, promoting fat gain. Urban children face additional risks from “academic pressure obesity,” characterized by prolonged study hours, reduced playtime, frequent snacking, and sedentary lifestyles exacerbated by safety concerns restricting outdoor play. Pediatricians must also be vigilant for secondary causes of obesity, such as genetic syndromes (e.g., Prader-Willi, Bardet-Biedl) due to consanguineous marriages, and endocrine disorders like hypothyroidism, particularly in regions with historical iodine deficiency. Regional differences further highlight variability, with North Indian children showing higher obesity rates, potentially linked to traditionally higher fat intake. Recognizing these culturally and regionally specific factors is essential for tailoring nutritional counseling and dietary interventions for obese children in India.

subtopics.subtopic_title: School-based interventions for preventing overnutrition
subtopics.concept: School-based interventions play a critical role in preventing overnutrition among children and adolescents, particularly in settings where childhood overweight and obesity are rising at alarming rates. Globally, approximately 18% of school-aged children are overweight or obese, affecting an estimated 200 million youth. In India, the prevalence of childhood overnutrition is significant, with 14.4 million obese children reported by 2017, making it the second highest globally after China. National data from the Comprehensive National Nutrition Survey (2016–18) revealed that 4% of Indian children aged 5–9 years and 5% of adolescents aged 10–19 years are overweight, while approximately 1% in each group meet criteria for obesity. Urban centers, particularly affluent populations, report higher rates, with combined overweight/obesity prevalence ranging from ~5% to 30%, as evidenced by multiple city and school-based studies. A meta-analysis of 52 Indian studies highlighted an increase in prevalence from 16.3% in the early 2000s to 19.3% after 2010, reflecting a steady upward trend. The severity of obesity is also escalating, with more children presenting with class 2 or class 3 obesity compared to previous decades. Pandemic-related lockdowns and reduced physical activity during COVID-19 further exacerbated weight gain in many youths, underscoring the urgency of preventive measures. For effective bedside decision-making, school-based interventions should focus on promoting healthy dietary habits, increasing physical activity, and fostering awareness about the risks of overnutrition. Practical strategies include implementing structured physical education programs, ensuring access to nutritious school meals, and integrating nutrition education into the curriculum. Screening for overnutrition using growth charts, BMI percentiles, and waist circumference measurements is essential to identify at-risk children early. Asian Indian children, who often exhibit a "thin-fat" phenotype with higher metabolic risk at lower BMIs, may benefit from tailored screening thresholds, such as using a waist circumference above the 70th percentile for age and gender. These targeted interventions, combined with community engagement and policy support, can help curb the rising epidemic of pediatric overnutrition and its associated long-term health risks.

subtopics.subtopic_title: Role of family and community in managing childhood obesity
subtopics.concept: The role of family and community is pivotal in managing childhood obesity, as both familial and environmental factors significantly influence a child’s risk of developing obesity. Familial factors, including parental obesity, play a critical role; a child has a 40% chance of becoming obese if one parent is obese, which increases to 80% if both parents are obese. This heightened risk stems from both genetic predispositions and shared family environments. For instance, certain polygenic traits may lead to increased appetite or efficient fat storage, while rare monogenic disorders (e.g., leptin or MC4R mutations) and genetic syndromes like Prader-Willi or Bardet-Biedl, though uncommon (<5–10% of cases), can result in severe obesity. Beyond genetics, family practices such as overfeeding, using food as a reward, or introducing sugar-sweetened beverages early in life (linked to a 4–5-fold higher obesity risk) can shape a child’s dietary habits and energy balance. Exclusive breastfeeding for at least six months has been shown to reduce obesity risk, while shorter durations are associated with several-fold higher odds of obesity. Community factors also play a crucial role, particularly in shaping physical activity and dietary environments. Urbanization has increased access to ultra-processed, energy-dense foods and sugary drinks, which are major contributors to childhood obesity. Additionally, modern lifestyles have reduced physical activity due to limited outdoor play spaces, packed academic schedules, and increased screen time. Screen exposure not only reduces energy expenditure but also promotes snacking and exposure to food advertising, further compounding the risk. Poor sleep habits, often associated with sedentary routines, can disrupt appetite-regulating hormones, exacerbating weight gain. Community-level interventions, such as creating safe play areas, promoting active commuting, and regulating food advertising, are essential to counter these trends. Thus, managing childhood obesity requires a collaborative approach, leveraging family practices and community resources to establish healthier dietary and activity patterns early in life.

subtopics.subtopic_title: Public health policies addressing childhood overnutrition in India
subtopics.concept:
Addressing childhood overnutrition in India requires public health policies that create environments conducive to healthier choices while limiting exposure to unhealthy options. One key strategy is regulating food environments, particularly in schools. The Food Safety and Standards Authority of India (FSSAI) has proposed regulations to ban the sale and promotion of High Fat, Salt, Sugar (HFSS) foods within 50 meters of school campuses, including items like chips, sugary drinks, and instant noodles. This policy aims to keep school zones free of such temptations, encouraging children to opt for healthier alternatives like fruits and milk. Some Indian states and boards, such as the Central Board of Secondary Education (CBSE), have issued similar guidelines, with enforcement efforts being pursued through courts. Another significant measure is Front-of-Pack Nutrition Labelling (FOPNL), which involves placing clear, easy-to-understand warning labels on the front of packaged foods high in sugar, salt, or saturated fat. Public health experts advocate for symbol-based warnings, such as red stop signs or black hexagons, rather than industry-preferred star ratings. Evidence from countries like Chile and Mexico shows that such labels can reduce the purchase of unhealthy items. The Supreme Court of India has also been involved in expediting FOPNL regulations, which, once implemented, would empower parents and older children to make informed food choices.

Restricting marketing and advertising of unhealthy foods to children is another critical policy area. Measures include limiting advertisements during children’s TV programs and digital platforms, banning cartoon characters or celebrity endorsements on junk food packaging, and discouraging misleading health claims. Advocacy efforts also focus on preventing HFSS food companies from sponsoring school events or distributing freebies. Economic strategies, such as taxation and pricing policies, can further disincentivize unhealthy consumption. While India has applied some sin taxes on sodas under the Goods and Services Tax (GST), public health experts call for dedicated soda taxes and higher levies on junk foods. Complementary subsidies or reduced taxes on fruits and vegetables could make healthier options more affordable. Together, these measures aim to create a supportive framework for combating childhood overnutrition.

subtopics.subtopic_title: Pharmacological and surgical interventions for severe obesity in children
subtopics.concept: Pharmacological and surgical interventions for severe obesity in children are considered when lifestyle modifications and behavioral interventions fail to achieve significant weight loss or when obesity is associated with serious comorbidities. Pharmacological treatments, though limited in pediatric populations, include FDA-approved medications like orlistat and liraglutide. Orlistat, a lipase inhibitor, is approved for use in children aged 12 years and older and works by reducing fat absorption in the gastrointestinal tract. However, its use is often limited by gastrointestinal side effects such as diarrhea and flatulence, and it requires adherence to a low-fat diet to minimize adverse effects. Liraglutide, a GLP-1 receptor agonist, is approved for adolescents aged 12 years and older and is administered as a daily subcutaneous injection. It aids in weight loss by reducing appetite and delaying gastric emptying, but common side effects include nausea and vomiting. Both medications require careful monitoring for efficacy and side effects, and their use should be part of a comprehensive weight management program. Surgical interventions, though rare in pediatric populations, may be considered for adolescents with severe obesity (BMI ≥40 or ≥35 with significant comorbidities) who have not responded to intensive lifestyle and pharmacological interventions. Bariatric procedures such as sleeve gastrectomy and Roux-en-Y gastric bypass are the most commonly performed surgeries in this age group. Sleeve gastrectomy involves the removal of a large portion of the stomach, reducing its capacity, while Roux-en-Y gastric bypass creates a small gastric pouch and bypasses a portion of the small intestine, leading to both restrictive and malabsorptive effects. These procedures have shown significant and sustained weight loss, as well as improvement or resolution of obesity-related comorbidities such as type 2 diabetes and hypertension. However, they require lifelong dietary modifications, supplementation to prevent nutritional deficiencies, and regular follow-up to monitor for complications such as micronutrient deficiencies or surgical issues. Decision-making for bariatric surgery in adolescents should involve a multidisciplinary team, including pediatricians, surgeons, dietitians, and mental health professionals, to ensure appropriate patient selection, preoperative preparation, and postoperative care.

subtopics.subtopic_title: Long-term monitoring and prevention of obesity-related complications
subtopics.concept:
In the Indian context, long-term monitoring and prevention of obesity-related complications require an understanding of unique early and late patterns of pediatric overnutrition. Early complications include metabolic risks even in children who do not appear obese by BMI criteria, a phenomenon described as the “thin-fat” Indian child. South Asian children, including Indians, exhibit higher body fat percentages and central adiposity at lower BMI thresholds compared to Caucasian peers. For instance, an Indian child with a BMI in the high-normal range, such as the 80th percentile, may still present with central obesity (waist circumference >90th percentile) and related complications like fatty liver or dyslipidemia. This has led to lower BMI cut-offs for overweight (adult BMI ≥23) in Asian populations and underscores the need to measure waist circumference and metabolic parameters in mildly overweight children. Late complications, such as insulin resistance, are exacerbated by cultural and dietary factors. Traditional diets rich in carbohydrates (e.g., rice, wheat) combined with ghee and sugar, as well as the dual availability of traditional sweets and Western fast foods in affluent families, increase caloric intake. Additionally, sedentary lifestyles driven by academic pressure and restricted outdoor play in urban areas contribute to obesity.

Red-flag warning signs include extreme hyperphagia, developmental delays, or dysmorphic features, which may indicate genetic obesity syndromes like Prader-Willi or Bardet-Biedl, particularly in regions with consanguineous marriages. Growth faltering in obese children should prompt evaluation for hypothyroidism, especially given India’s history of iodine deficiency. Regional variations also exist, with higher obesity rates observed in North Indian states like Punjab and Delhi, potentially due to traditionally higher fat intake.

Pathophysiologically, central adiposity and insulin resistance at lower BMI thresholds are hallmarks of obesity in Indian children, necessitating tailored approaches. Bedside monitoring should include regular assessment of BMI, waist circumference, and metabolic parameters, with escalation to genetic or endocrine evaluations when indicated. Definitive management involves individualized dietary counseling that accounts for cultural preferences, promotion of physical activity, and addressing sedentary behaviors. Follow-up should focus on sustained lifestyle modifications, early detection of complications, and family education to reframe perceptions of “plumpness” as a health concern.
